to officially allow someone to leave somewhere, especially the hospital or the army, navy etc, or to tell them that they must leave
discharge yourself British English (=leave hospital before your treatment is complete)
Hospitals now tend to discharge patients earlier than in the past.
Dunning was conditionally discharged for two years.
Several of the recruits were discharged from the Army due to medical problems.
to send out gas, liquid, smoke etc, or to allow it to escape
Sewage is discharged directly into the sea.
Rainwater collects here and then discharges into the river Kennett.
to fire a gun or shoot an arrow etc
A soldier accidentally discharged his weapon.
to do or pay what you have a duty to do or pay
The trustees failed to discharge their duties properly.
if a piece of electrical equipment discharges, or if it is discharged, it sends out electricity
if a wound or body part discharges a substance such as pus (=infected liquid), the substance slowly comes out of it
to take goods or passengers off a ship, plane etc
when you officially allow someone to leave somewhere, especially the hospital or their job in the army, navy etc
Nurses visit the mother and baby for two weeks after their discharge from the hospital.
when gas, liquid, smoke etc is sent out, or the substance that is sent out
the discharge of toxic waste into the sea
when a substance slowly comes out of a wound or part of your body, or the substance that comes out
electricity that is sent out by a piece of equipment, a storm etc
when someone performs a duty or pays a debt
the discharge of the college’s legal responsibilities
to officially allow or tell someone to leave hospital, the army, a job etc
The men were treated for minor injuries and discharged.
He was discharged from the RAF last August.
to remove someone from their job
In December, the airline discharged 49 employees and said it might need to make further cuts.
to do properly everything that is part of a particular duty etc
The committee said that the Bank had failed to discharge its supervisory duties.
to completely pay an amount that is owed
The payment of £4,000 together with the monthly sum of £1,000 was not enough to discharge in full the invoice for January’s work.
to send out gas, liquid, smoke etc, or allow it to escape
Gas leaked from the tanker as it discharged crude oil at the refinery.
pollutants being discharged into the atmosphere
to take goods off a ship, plane etc
The ship discharged the 2,911-tonne cargo of 330 concrete-coated steel pipes in less than a day.
to state officially that someone who was bankrupt has obeyed the court and can do business again
when someone is officially allowed or told to leave hospital, the army, a job etc
The organization helps ex-servicemen and their dependants following discharge from the forces.
when someone is removed from their job
He threatened to sue the firm for wrongful discharge.
when someone performs a duty, responsibility etc properly and thoroughly
Although we do not consider Mr Gray’s conduct to have been dishonest, the discharge of his responsibilities as company secretary was most unsatisfactory.
when an amount such as a debt or money claimed on an insurance policy is completely paid
the residue of the estate after the discharge of all debts and liabilities
when gas, liquid, smoke etc is sent out or allowed to escape
the discharge of toxic waste into the sea
£1 billion has been spent to control sewage discharges.
when goods are taken off a ship, plane etc
Checking the discharge of cargo is part of my job.
